item.title: Presidents Are Limited to Two Terms. He’s Running for His Fourth.
item.description: The main opposition candidates in the Ivory Coast’s presidential election have been barred from the race. Critics say the vote has been rigged.

item.title: U.S. Deploys Aircraft Carrier to Latin America as Drug Operation Expands
item.description: The Trump administration has acknowledged 10 strikes on suspected drug-smuggling boats from South America, which have killed 43 people.

item.title: Trump Leaves Behind a Reeling Washington to Chase a Deal With China
item.description: President Trump is embarking on a six-day diplomatic tour of Asia, testing his role as a statesman and negotiator as he pursues a trade deal with Beijing.

item.title: Trump’s Asia Tour: Deals, Diplomacy and a Meeting With Xi
item.description: From Kuala Lumpur to Gyeongju, President Trump is casting himself as a deal-maker and peace negotiator, while a wary region looks for tariff relief and steadier ties.

item.title: Asia, Caught in the Middle, Faces Trump and Xi’s Tug of War
item.description: President Trump’s visit shows how the United States and China are vying for influence in Asia over trade, technology and the fate of Taiwan.

item.title: Pumpkin Spice Lattes, a Favorite U.S. Fall Drink, Divide Europe
item.description: One of America’s favorite fall drinks shows up in Brussels and Antwerp, but rarely in Paris and Rome. It has yet to reach the ubiquity — or the sugar content — of its stateside counterpart.

item.title: In Fight Against Malaria, an Unexpected — and Snuggly — Shield
item.description: Treating baby wraps with a mosquito repellent shows promising protection against a top killer of children.

item.title: U.S. Imposes Sanctions on Colombia’s Leader, One of Trump’s Harshest Critics
item.description: The United States Treasury Department accused President Gustavo Petro of allowing drug trafficking to flourish.

item.title: South Korea Tries to Curb Anti-China Protests Ahead of Xi Visit
item.description: The recent surge in demonstrations by far-right groups presents a challenge for the South Korean government, as it prepares to host both Xi Jinping, the leader of China, and President Trump.

item.title: Sirikit, Glamorous Former Queen of Thailand Who Wielded Power, Dies at 93
item.description: As the wife of King Bhumibol Adulyadej, she traveled the world charming government leaders and the public.

item.title: Nebojsa Pavkovic, Yugoslav General Convicted of War Crimes, Dies at 79
item.description: Found guilty in 2009, he had been serving a 22-year sentence but was released for health reasons at the request of the Serbian government.

item.title: Trump and Canada’s Trade Spat Spotlights Doug Ford, the Ontario Premier
item.description: Doug Ford has built a reputation for picking fights with President Trump and getting under his skin with publicity-grabbing moves as U.S. tariffs have harmed Ontario’s economy.

item.title: A Pilgrim Route in Norway: Berries, Bogs and a Viking King
item.description: Following one of the nine St. Olav Ways, a photographer trudged with soggy feet through tundras, forests and wetlands. Here’s what she saw.

item.title: Nepal’s Gen Z Sees Little Hope at Home
item.description: The protests that rocked Nepal were about more than a social media ban. The economy is so dire that for many, going abroad seems the only way to build a future.

item.title: A Missing Picasso Is Found, and a Small Spanish Town Loses Its Air of Mystery
item.description: For a brief moment, the puzzle of what had happened to Pablo Picasso’s “Still Life With Guitar” infected Deifontes with caper fever.

item.title: Ukraine’s ‘Coalition of the Willing’ Has the Wind at Its Back
item.description: Britain hosted a meeting of European leaders to discuss bolstering support for Kyiv as winter approaches.

item.title: Trump to Investigate Whether China Abided by 2020 Trade Deal
item.description: The administration announced its trade investigation on Friday, ahead of a summit between U.S. and Chinese leaders.

item.title: Trump Officials Float New Plan for Abrego Garcia: Send Him to Liberia
item.description: The proposal was the latest twist in a byzantine saga that has transformed the Salvadoran migrant into one of the best-known symbols of President Trump’s aggressive deportation agenda.

item.title: In a First for a Woman in France, Life Sentence Imposed for Murder of Schoolgirl
item.description: Dahbia Benkired, an Algerian woman, was convicted of raping and killing 12-year-old Lola Daviet, in a case that outraged France and raised questions about the deportation of migrants.

item.title: UK Man is Sentenced for Pro-Russian Attack Plots
item.description: Dylan Earl recruited people to set fire to two London warehouses containing aid bound for Ukraine, the police said. He was also convicted of plotting against a dissident Russian restaurant owner.

item.title: King Charles and Pope Leo Pray Together in Groundbreaking Moment
item.description: It was the first time in hundreds of years that the leaders of the Roman Catholic and Anglican Churches prayed together, offering a public display of unity.

item.title: U.S. Flies Drones Over Gaza to Monitor Cease-Fire, Officials Say
item.description: The surveillance missions are part of a U.S.-led international effort to ensure the fragile cease-fire between Israel and Hamas holds.

item.title: Drug-Smuggling Submarines on Display at Latin American Naval Base
item.description: A display of confiscated vessels at a naval base in Ecuador offers a peek at why drug smuggling is so hard to stop.

item.title: Trump Says He’s Cutting Off Trade Negotiations With Canada
item.description: The president said he was motivated by an ad, paid for by the province of Ontario, that featured Ronald Reagan criticizing tariffs in a 1987 radio address.

item.title: After the Mexican Cartel Comes, They Pick Up the Pieces
item.description: They arrive where the killings end, retrieving bodies, comforting families and bearing the emotional toll of a deadly struggle that shows no sign of stopping.

item.title: Trump Official Warns California Against Arresting Federal Agents
item.description: Deputy U.S. Attorney General Todd Blanche told top California leaders that they would be prosecuted if they arrested federal agents performing immigration raids.

item.title: U.S. Diplomats Will Work With Troops to Maintain Gaza Cease-Fire, Rubio Says
item.description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio said during a visit to Israel that the State Department would increase its presence at a center set up to monitor the peace deal.

item.title: Fire Engulfs Bus in Southern India, Killing 20
item.description: A motorcycle struck the bus and got lodged in it, creating sparks that ignited the fuel tank, the police in Andhra Pradesh State said.

item.title: Who Were the 2,000 Palestinians Freed by Israel?
item.description: Under the cease-fire deal, Israel released 250 Palestinians serving long sentences for violent attacks. More than 1,700 others had been detained in Gaza and held without charge.

item.title: A Quick Route to Rebuild Half of Gaza, or Another U.S. Pipe Dream?
item.description: There are many questions about whether a plan to rebuild Israeli-held parts of the enclave is feasible or doomed from the outset.

item.title: Blue Jays Face Dodgers in World Series With All of Canada Behind Them
item.description: The Blue Jays and the Dodgers play Game 1 of the World Series tonight, and for Canada’s team home-field advantage is as big as the entire country.

item.title: Labour Party Suffers Crushing Defeat in Wales Special Election
item.description: The governing party placed a distant third in a special election for a district of Wales it has dominated for a century. Plaid Cymru, a center-left Welsh nationalist party, won.

item.title: Estonia, a Tiny NATO Nation, Is Cashing In on the Threat Next Door
item.description: As fears about Russia grow, Estonia’s tech-savvy work force is developing new weapons and defense systems.

item.title: With Power Move on Rare Earths, China Plays Both Victim and Bully
item.description: In weaponizing its dominance over the crucial minerals, Beijing is using tactics that it once denounced, potentially alienating nations it wants to court.

item.title: German Company Launches Ad After Its Lift Is Used in Louvre Heist
item.description: The brazen daylight robbery of the Louvre on Sunday has turned into a marketing opportunity for Böcker, a German maker of cranes and elevators whose product was used in the heist.

item.title: Europe’s Persistence in Supporting Ukraine Is Bearing Fruit
item.description: European leaders want to build on President Trump’s sanctions on Russia with new commitments of financial and military support for Kyiv.

item.title: The White House Wrecking Ball
item.description: President Trump’s demolition of the East Wing to make way for a ballroom seems to mirror his determination to remake America.

item.title: U.S. May Seek United Nations Mandate for Gaza Security Force, Rubio Says
item.description: Vice President JD Vance spoke from Israel, as he wrapped up a visit aimed at shoring up a fragile cease-fire between Israel and Hamas.

item.title: Staghorn and Elkhorn Coral Are Functionally Extinct Off Florida, Researchers Say
item.description: Elkhorn and staghorn coral are now functionally extinct around the state, researchers say, meaning they no longer play any significant role in their ecosystem.

item.title: U.S. to Investigate China’s Compliance With 2020 Trade Deal
item.description: The trade case is coming at a pivotal moment, before a meeting next week between President Trump and China’s leader.

item.title: A Mystery in Trinidad as Bodies Wash Ashore After U.S. Strikes
item.description: The U.S. campaign targeting what it says is drug trafficking from Venezuela has exposed Trinidad to the fallout: unidentified bodies with burn marks and missing limbs showing up in its territory.

item.title: Can Europe Agree on Turning Frozen Russian Assets Into Cash for Ukraine?
item.description: European Union officials want to make a large loan to Ukraine backed by Russian state assets, but on Thursday, they deferred any clear decision on that plan to December.

item.title: Pakistan Bans Radical Islamist Party After Deadly Clashes
item.description: The move underscores the country’s struggle to contain religious extremism without provoking influential clerics who can summon thousands of supporters to the streets.

item.title: Trump Says Israeli Annexation of West Bank Land ‘Won’t Happen’
item.description: Vice President JD Vance also called symbolic votes in Israel’s Parliament to take territory a “very stupid political stunt.”

item.title: ‘Brother Wang,’ Accused of Being Drug Cartel Fixer, Is Arrested in Cuba
item.description: Zhi Dong Zhang, who escaped house arrest in Mexico this summer, is accused of supplying cartels with fentanyl from China, smuggling and money laundering millions under the alias “Brother Wang.”

item.title: Oil Price Jumps on Trump’s Russia Sanctions
item.description: Traders are pondering whether the United States and its allies are finally getting serious about restricting Russian energy.

item.title: Putin Calls U.S. Sanctions ‘Unfriendly Act’ and Says Russia Won’t Bend
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin warned of an overwhelming response if the Trump administration arms Kyiv with powerful missiles it seeks.

item.title: British Soldier Is Acquitted of Murder in 1972 Bloody Sunday Massacre
item.description: The former paratrooper, referred to only as Soldier F, was found not guilty more than a half-century after his unit in Northern Ireland killed 14 unarmed civilians.

item.title: Trump Supporters Are Uneasy About Military Actions Against Venezuela
item.description: Some conservative policy advisers and commentators, including Laura Loomer and Stephen K. Bannon, are raising questions about the administration’s policy in the region.

item.title: She Worked on Tsunami Alerts. Then She Was Fired.
item.description: “I always wanted to be a public servant and do science for the good of the people,” said Corina Allen, who lost her job at NOAA.

item.title: E.U. Approves Sweeping Sanctions Targeting Russian Gas and Crypto
item.description: European leaders signed off on the new measures just hours after President Trump imposed sanctions on Russia’s two biggest oil companies.

item.title: Trump Imposes Sanctions on Russian Oil Companies as His Frustration With Putin Mounts
item.description: The sanctions are among the most significant measures that the United States has taken against the Russian energy sector since the beginning of the war in Ukraine.

item.title: Britain’s Labour Party Criticizes Farage Over Ties to U.S. Anti-Abortion Group
item.description: The governing party said it was “deeply concerning” that Nigel Farage’s appearance in the U.S. Congress had been brokered by an organization that helped topple Roe v. Wade.

item.title: Can a Beach Really Be Evil? Ask the Sun-Seekers in Good Sahel.
item.description: The sea looks the same. So does the sand. But in Egypt, two beach communities not far from each other have decidedly different ideas about fun.

item.title: Chinese Impersonator’s Trump Act Has Won Him Millions of Fans
item.description: Ryan Chen has turned an uncanny impersonation of President Trump into a social media career, and a mirror of China’s fascination with America.

item.title: What to Know About the Billion-Dollar Scam Center Industry
item.description: The United States, Britain and South Korea have joined a crackdown on groups running frauds from Southeast Asia. They have their work cut out.

item.title: The Steep Cost of A.I.
item.description: Some countries are trying hard not to be left out of the race for artificial intelligence. But this choice comes with consequences.

item.title: Iceland Says It Is No Longer Mosquito-Free
item.description: Iceland was one of the only mosquito-free places in the world, at least according to its records. Not anymore.

item.title: Congress Members Question Defense Department’s Delay in PFAS Cleanup
item.description: A bipartisan group of lawmakers has asked the military to explain why cleanup of PFAS chemicals at bases nationwide has been pushed back.

item.title: At a Mass Burial in Gaza, Palestinians Mourn the Unknown Dead
item.description: Under the terms of a cease-fire deal, Israel and Hamas have been exchanging remains, but Gaza’s medical authorities have not been able to identify many of them.

item.title: What Are Gripen Fighter Jets and Why Does Ukraine Want Them From Sweden?
item.description: The Swedish warplanes are well suited to the rugged combat operations Ukraine will have to carry out, experts say.
